thread.title: RBS spin-off Williams and Glynn not ready for customers
thread.title_full: RBS spin-off Williams and Glynn not ready for customers

title: RBS spin-off Williams and Glynn not ready for customers
text:
14,000.00 -250.00 
Competition authorities want to assess W&G's impact on the market, but cannot because the bank's business plan and licence application are not complete 
New (KOSDAQ: 160550.KQ - news ) bank Williams and Glyn (W&G) has not given the licencing and competition authorities all the documents they need to decide if the lender is ready to face customers, and to assess its impact on competition in the banking market. 
W&G is being spun off from Royal Bank of Scotland (LSE: RBS.L - news ) under the terms of its 2008 taxpayer bailout, in a bid to introduce more competition into the industry and reduce the dominance of the biggest banks. 
As a result, RBS has put 5,000 staff to work building a new IT platform and setting up the new bank with 1.4m retail customers and 200,000 business accounts, as well as 314 branches. 
W&G hopes to float on the stock market in the final quarter of 2016, and while RBS maintains that the plan is still on track, the project has been beset by delays , including problems with the IT structure. 
The Competition and Markets Authority had hoped to be able to respond to the Chancellor’s request for an assessment of the spin-off’s impact on competition in the market by now, but the Treasury has announced the CMA has not received a final copy of the new bank’s business plan. 
Such an assessment is of vital importance if the authorities decide that W&G will not have a big enough impact, RBS could be ordered to move more customers and branches into the unit. 
It is understood that the problem goes back further than the CMA W&G is applying for a banking licence, and only when it has received the thumbs-up from the Bank of England’s Prudential Regulation Authority can the CMA be confident that the business plan is indeed the final version. 
And RBS has not given sufficient information to the PRA to make that decision, meaning it cannot yet be given a licence and the knock-on effect runs into the CMA. 
The business plan is a lengthy document which includes details on the bank’s ownership, strategy, target market, edge over rivals, future expansion plans, funding structure, management and dozens of other topics. 
The CMA now hopes these hurdles will be overcome and it will be able to make a ruling by the end of the year. 
“We are devoting significant resources to establish Williams & Glyn as a viable, stand-alone bank that will bring increased competition to the UK banking market,” said RBS. “We are focused on achieving the best possible outcome for customers, with an IPO planned for Q4 2016.” 
W&G will be run by chief executive Jim Brown, who formerly ran RBS’s Ulster bank, and the lender has appointed Westpac executive Leigh Bartlett as its first permanent chief finance officer.
